links.title: Protect Stockton's Street Dogs
links.description:
The Stockton street dog situation looks like something out of a third world country, not the economic powerhouse of the United States.
Hundreds of dogs are chained, starving, and dehydrated. No food, no water, no shelter, no room to move. Abuse is happening openly while the people in charge stand by and watch.
In just a couple of weekends, two separate brand-new litters of puppies appeared and had to be rushed into homes so they didn’t end up dead or back in the same nightmare.
And through all of it, there are only two consistent presences on the ground: Jesse, of @StocktonStreetDogs and @cydnikeala, the only people trying to hold back a tidal wave of suffering while those with the power and the budgets look away and line their pockets with taxpayer money.

links.title: Stop the Mass Slaughter of Street Dogs in India
links.description:
On August 11th, 2025, India’s Supreme Court ordered all stray dogs in Delhi-NCR to be removed from public spaces and locked away in shelters, with no return to their home streets.

Even though a later bench called that “too harsh” and talked about sterilise-vaccinate-return with designated feeding zones, the damage was done. People heard exactly what they wanted to hear: the dogs are the problem, and getting rid of them is acceptable.

Since then, we’ve seen what that looks like on the ground.
Dogs beaten with sticks and iron rods.
Dogs rounded up and dumped in places with no food, water or shelter.
A dog in Jaipur tied by the legs and thrown onto a live transformer, electrocuted to death while his caretaker screamed.

This is state-sanctioned cruelty by silence.

India’s Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act still values a dog’s suffering at ₹10-50 ($0.11-0.56) for a first offence. Even repeat offenders can walk away with a token fine and a few months in jail, if that.

TNVR, trap, neuter, vaccinate, return, works. It reduces bites. It controls rabies. It stabilises street dog populations. But killing, dumping and looking the other way is cheaper in the short term. Once again, money matters more than life.

India loves to sell itself as the land of ahimsa, of compassion for all living beings. Right now, its streets tell a very different story.

India’s tourism industry is projected to pump tens of billions into the economy in 2025. If the government and the courts want to ignore the blood on the pavements, then it’s time to hit them where it hurts most, their wallet.

Cancel the yoga retreats and tiger safaris.
Skip the spiritual “bucket list” tours.
Choose countries that actually enforce cruelty laws.

Until India stops turning its street dogs into punching bags and corpses, it does not deserve your money.

links.title: Stop The Cat and Dog Meat Trade in China
links.summary:
China removed dogs from the national livestock list in 2020. Because there are no national animal welfare laws in China, dogs now have no legal rights.

No food animal status means no food-safety framework, no lawful slaughter rules, and no transport standards, resulting in a black market of stolen pets, back-alley killing, menu fraud, and trucks moving animals across the country in the dark.

A superstitious belief that more pain means better meat, and no binding standards, leads to dogs boiled alive, blowtorched alive, skinned alive, and savagely beaten.

Shenzhen and Zhuhai banned it outright. The rest of the country hasn’t.
So dogs and cats now exist in a loophole: not approved as food, not banned everywhere, which means fewer protections and more suffering.

"It's their culture/tradition" is a copout and ignorance talking. You wouldn't give a free pass to "cultural/traditional" child brides, slavery, or honor killings elsewhere.
China needs a national ban on slaughter, transport, sale, and advertising. Licenses pulled. Markets closed. Raids on supply lines. Public enforcement reports.

Stop Ugandan Rescue Scams
links.description: A cluster of Instagram/Facebook pages posing as dog rescues. They don’t rescue; they manufacture cruelty. Dogs are starved, injured on purpose, or left untreated so photos look shocking. The goal is simple: squeeze donations from decent people. When one dog stops performing (i.e., healing), another “urgent case” appears. Same script, different wounds.
links.description2: Stage or prolong suffering → post daily "updates" → guilt-trip → collect via instant-pay links → disappear/recycle content. Use throwaway admins and burner numbers. When flagged, they rename, pivot, or move to a new handle.
links.description3Title: Red flags to look out for
description3: Money first, transparency never: PayPal.me / mobile money / Western Union only; no registered charity number, no audited reports, no vet invoices.
Geo nonsense: Claims "Uganda shelter" while geotags/photos hop across countries or time zones. Stock photos of "Africa" sprinkled in.
High followers, dead engagement: Bought audience; low comments/likes that don’t match follower count.
Recycled media: Same dog, same injury, posted for months with "urgent surgery today!" Reverse-image search catches repeats.
No real-world footprint: No website or a 1-page site with stolen copy; no Google Maps listing; no legitimate adoption process or contracts.
Pressure tactics: "Only YOU can save him in the next hour," mass tagging, DM spamming, guilt trips if you ask for proof.
Vague or shifting details: Dog’s name, age, location, and diagnosis change post to post.
Medical fantasy: Miraculous diagnoses, dramatic before/after collages, never a verifiable vet name, clinic address, or itemized bill.
Comment control: Critical questions deleted, comments turned off, or replies move instantly to DMs.
Verified-but-hijacked look: Sometimes a verified or old account repurposed (handle changed, old content wiped).
Logistics that make no sense: Offering international adoptions but no import/export compliance or quarantine info.
Donation links, zero governance: No trustees, no policy pages (safeguarding, returns, complaints), no annual reports—just the donate button.

links.title: Puppy Neglect In Lewisville, TX
links.description:
This poor puppy is shut out day and night. Sometimes there's a crate, sometimes there isn't. He's had no protection from the recent storms in the area.
Under Texas Penal Code §42.092, this appears to meet the definition of:
- Unreasonably failing to provide necessary shelter and care for an animal in one’s custody (§42.092(b)(3)); and
- Confining an animal in a cruel manner (§42.092(b)(5)).
The owner claims they work 12-hour shifts and “has to” shut the puppy out or he will soil the house. And yet the puppy is shut out with no shelter, whilst the owner is home.
Animal services have been called, but aren't taking the situation seriously. Forecasts in Lewisville expect temperatures of 30°F next week, cold enough to cause severe illness or death if he's shut out without shelter.

links.title: Demand Animal Welfare Laws in Vietnam
links.description: There are currently no comprehensive animal welfare laws in Vietnam. Any protections animals have are flimsy at best and nestled into other legislation, leaving plenty of wiggle room for loopholes to be exploited. Due to these exploits, dogs and cats are stolen from the streets to be slaughtered in deplorable conditions with no legal consequences. A ban on dog meat has been in effect in Hanoi since 2021, but there is no national ban yet, despite 64% of Vietnamese people supporting one.
